title: I never realized how harsh the instant feedback system has gotten
body:
Before you read it and think it's just another rant of oh why did I get banned, trust me, its different.

I haven't played league a lot lately, I just started getting back after a few months of barely playing. I've never been punished for anything before either. I don't use chat often, if at all. But today in the one game a day I've been playing to have fun I did something I'll admit was out of the ordinary. I wrote kys. And I also bmed a little. But I did it in just one game. In this past week I've been getting back to league I have barely written in chat at all.

The chat log reads
Cabruh: kysd
Cabruh: kys
Cabruh: ok dont kys
Cabruh: all bot
Cabruh: gg
Cabruh: u lose
Cabruh: haha

literally thats it

so the first 3 lines, when taken out of context, seem like I targeted someone for no reason. Thing is, I meant it jokingly to the person who just dcd from the game. He never really saw it. When he reconnected, I wrote "ok dont kys" kind of as a joking manner to which I meant to tell my other teammates, "oh hes back, we dont have to remake and waste time". There are understandable frustrations with players who dc and force a remake. If a rioter checks it, theyll see the timestamps check out for when the player dcs and reconnects.

I'll admit that I was kind of dickish to write haha and u lose at the end. I don't know if the system picked up on it but I'll admit it was kind of wrong, kind of like saying ggez (though lots of people get away with that)

I just don't know. When the chat is taken completely out of context and is read by a robot who finds one uncensored 3 letter word and I get a 14 day ban because of it, I just feel a little pushed away from a game I was hoping to get back into on the verge of worlds. I'm in high school, and I know I'm a little bit crude and edgy, but I really love messing around with friends on league. This feels a bit harsh and makes me kind of upset I can't do that at all for the next two weeks.

I believe Riot has said they're harder on new accounts that act toxic than level 30+ accounts in an attempt to stop toxic smurfs, but I've only ever made one account so I don't know first hand if that seems true.

Lets agree that dumping toxic players into the new player population is akin to dumping your sewage upstream of where you get your drinking water - a bad idea and starts to kill off the population. 

Corralling toxic players into a separate queue is also called "Prisoner's Island", and while it does work to separate the regular players from the toxic players it has a few drawbacks. First, it's very hard for players who get there to ever get back out. They are constantly surrounded by toxic players, which re-enforces the idea that behavior is normal. It also creates worse matchmaking for the players involved due to a smaller queue population. If matchmaking is too bad or takes too long then people would create new accounts in hopes of getting better matches again, which brings us back to the original problem (and makes the queue times even longer for those who stick to their original accounts, making them more likely to smurf as well). There's a lot of ways it could fail, making it less than ideal.

Another popular idea is to prevent toxic players from ever typing. Riot is skeptical of this one due to their observations from when chat restrictions infinitely stacked. They say they saw those with tons of chat restrictions turning to inting or trolling more often, and since those are harder behaviors to detect they decided to switch to the current system. However, there's a chance that an alternative method of restricting chat may work better. If overly toxic players were to start games automatically muted by everyone else, then the other players could opt-in to hearing them. If they don't change their ways, only those who noticed they were muted and chose to unmute them have to hear it. With pings being drastically better than before, it should be easier for them to communicate with their team even when muted, which could prevent some of the trolling/inting that happened in earlier seasons.
